bestBHT.bht: Caiaphas, the high priest, advised that one man should die for the people, in accordance with God's plan and a prophecy. Jesus, aware of his fate, stood before Caiaphas, bound and submissive. His death was not merely as a martyr or example, but as a surety for God's chosen people, procuring their salvation and satisfying divine justice. Through his sacrificial death, Jesus secured the application of salvation by the Holy Spirit to those whom God had elected as his special people.

Henry Alford: 14.] See ch. xi, 49–52 and notes; also on the words, that year, ver, 13.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 14. Now Caiaphas was he, which gave
counsel to the Jews, that it was expedient that one man should die
Albert Barnes: This is referred to here, probably, to show how little prospect there was that Jesus would have justice done him in the hands of a man who had already pronounced on the case.
John Calvin: God employed the foul mouth of a wicked and treacherous high priest to utter a prediction...
...just as he guided the tongue of the prophet Baham, contrary to his wish...
...he was constrained to bless the people, though he desired to curse them, to gain favor with king Balak...
Philip Schaff: The reason why Jesus was taken to Annas first is not to be found in the mere fact of his relationship to Caiaphas, but that it is to be sought also in that character of the latter which, it was hoped, would influence the former."
Caiaphas had lost self-control, and had become a mere instrument in the hands of higher powers who were urging him onward to fill up the measure of his guilt."
Before this powerful man then Jesus stands, bound, submissive, knowing the fate that is before Him.
Archibald T. Robertson: He which gave command (ο συμβουλευσας). First aorist active articular participle of συμβουλευω, old verb (Matthew 26:4). The reference is to John 11:50.
It was expedient (συμφερε). Present active indicative retained in indirect assertion after secondary tense (ην, was).
Here we have the second aorist active infinitive αποθανειν as the subject of συμφερε, both good idioms in the Koine.
John Gill: The people Christ was to die for, was not all the, people of the world, nor only the people of the Jews, nor all of them; but all the elect of God, whom God has chosen for his special and peculiar people, and has given to Christ as such.

These Christ were to die for, and did, not merely as a martyr, to confirm his doctrine to them, or as an example to teach them meekness, patience, and courage, but in the room and stead of them, as a surety for them.

It was expedient that he should, in such sense, die for them, because of his suretyship engagements, that he might make satisfaction to the law and justice of God, and procure the salvation of his people, and send forth the Spirit to make application of it to them.

bhtAttempts.bht: Caiaphas, the high priest, was the one who had given counsel to the Jews that it was necessary for one man to die for the people. This counsel was in line with God's plan, as it was prophesied in John 11:50. Despite the unjust circumstances surrounding Jesus' trial, it is clear that divine intervention was at play. Caiaphas, though a wicked and treacherous high priest, served as an instrument to fulfill God's purposes. Jesus submitted himself to this powerful man, bound and aware of the fate that awaited him. His death was not merely as a martyr or example, but as a surety for the elect of God, whom Jesus died for in their place, to satisfy the law and justice of God and procure their salvation.

Caiaphas, the high priest, gave counsel that one man should die for the people, which was a fulfillment of a prophecy in John 11:50. Though unjust, Jesus submitted to Caiaphas, knowing his fate. His death was not just as a martyr or example, but as a surety for the elect of God, procuring their salvation. Jesus's death satisfied the law and justice of God, securing the application of salvation through the Holy Spirit to those chosen by God as His special people.

Caiaphas, the high priest, advised that it was necessary for one man to die for the people. This counsel was in line with God's plan and a fulfillment of the prophecy in John 11:50. Despite the unfair circumstances, Jesus submitted to Caiaphas, aware of his impending fate. His death was not merely as a martyr or example, but as a surety for the chosen people of God, procuring their salvation and satisfying divine justice so that the Holy Spirit may apply this salvation to them.

Caiaphas, the high priest, played a significant role in the plot against Jesus by advising that it was necessary for one man to die for the people. Fulfilling the prophecy from John 11:50, Jesus willingly submitted himself to this powerful man, understanding his predetermined fate. His death went beyond martyrdom or setting an example; it served as a substitutionary sacrifice for the elect of God, satisfying divine justice, securing their salvation, and allowing the Holy Spirit to apply it to them.

Caiaphas, the high priest, advised that one man should die for the people, in accordance with God's plan and a prophecy. Jesus, aware of his fate, stood before Caiaphas, bound and submissive. His death was not merely as a martyr or example, but as a surety for God's chosen people, procuring their salvation and satisfying divine justice. Through his sacrificial death, Jesus secured the application of salvation by the Holy Spirit to those whom God had elected as his special people.
